reviewText: I have watched a couple of Daoist monk Zhou, Xuan-Yun's DVDs now, and he is an extremely accomplished martial artist.  Watching him move is a pleasure, and it is obvious that he has spent many years training.  In this DVD, "Wudang Sword: Tai Yi Daoist Form," the Wudang Tai Yi Daoist sword sequence is presentedThe beginning introduction and history sections have a voice narating, with Zhou, Xuan-Yun performing various forms in some very beautiful locations.  For those that appreciate China and the flowing movement of a sword form, it is a pleasure to watch.  It contains a brief introduction to Wudang sword and history.The next sections cover information about the sword, selection and care, and etiquette and safety.  I really liked that the etiquette and safety was included because it is an important aspect that is sometimes neglected by non-serious martial artists that just want to grab someone's weapon and not treat is properly.From there, the program covers grip, principles of Wudang sword, training drills that include stance drills and sword drills, a little about the sword form, demonstration of the sword form from the front and rear slow, a fast demonstration, instruction on the form, and finally martial applications from the form are shown.In the short conclusion, Zhou, Xuan-Yun shares that the purpose to practice sword is for health and to better control your body and movements.  He then thanks his assistants.  The entire program is 100 minutes long, and the menu makes it easy to select the chapter you wish to review.  The package insert also contains the 67 steps to the form in Chinese and English.The instruction is in Chinese with English subtitles, or you can choose to watch with an English translation voice over with English subtitles.  I really prefer when the instructor teaches to the camera, rather than voice overs.  Unfortunately for me, I don't understand Chinese, so I have to read the subtitles and listen to the English narration.The Wudang Sword form is very different from the Korean and Japanese sword I am more familiar with.  Because of that, I personally watched the video for the history and to be exposed to the form and training, not so much that I will add this form to my existing training program.  However, for those that practice Chinese arts and want to learn this Wudang sword form, this DVD will be very valuable as you practice and learn.  I recommend it highly to those that wish to learn this form, and also recommend it to those, like me, who wish to learn more about this art and see it performed in some beautiful locations.Reviewed by Alain Burrese, J.D., author of the Lock On Joint Locking Essentials series.
summary: Very good DVD for those interested in the Wudang Sword Tai Yi Daoist form

reviewText: I Love the Sword Very much. It is a part of my everyday life, and when I see something done with the sword that I am unfamiliar with it is exciting. The forum is inspirational and if someone were to practice these movements, not only would there sword development improve, so would all aspects of there standing martial arts.  I recommend this video to anyone who has a interest in health, and or sword development. the movements practiced would help develop everything a growing martial artist needs. My background with the sword is very back yard bokken sticks, and cutting small trees and big branches, very karate. This video, has opened many doors for my applications, and style. I feel any martial art style could take what they find in this video, if it be one technique, train it into what they do, and only good things would come of it.Damian

reviewText: Starts off excellent...  Stays excellent... Then, it gets better!YMAA is the Detroit Red Wings of the Martial Arts world.  They set the bar very high  and continually meet that standard for quality instructional DVDs and martial arts publications.  Here, with the "WUDANG SWORD, Tai Yi Daoist Form" DVD, they may have gone to the next level.The DVD includes instructional and informational scenes set against breathtaking views from ancient temples, beautiful forests and striking mountain tops.  This alone does not make an instructional video good; rather it demonstrates the commitment of those involved in developing this DVD.  It starts with background and instruction as to the history and structure of the sword and from there it moves on to the actual form itself.Zhou, Xuan-Yun is remarkable both in his form and ability to communicate.  The DVD is structured to lead you, step by step, through the learning process.  The form itself is shown from multiple angles and speeds.  The DVD then offers chapters on the postures in the form along with oral instruction on those postures.  It also includes a complete chapter on the martial applications of those postures.  If this were not enough (and it really is), included are chapters on drills for developing the wrists (sword), legs (footwork) and stances.
summary: This is the most instructionally effective martial arts video I have ever witnessed
Title: N/A

reviewText: >  Superb martial artist Zhou, Xuan-Yun has collaborated with Producer/Director David Silver to create another excellent Martial Arts teaching DVD. In their latest release Zhou teaches the Wudang Sword Tai Yi Daoist Form. The insert in the DVD lists all of the moves in the form in English and Chinese.>>  Many viewers of Zhou's Wudang Taijiquan DVD were amazed by the very powerful set demonstrated and taught by Zhou. This Wudang Sword form also shows a level of power seldom seen in the majority of Taiji sword forms taught. Zhou is a very skilled and well taught martial artist. David Silver brings an equal level of skill to the production aspects of this DVD.>>  As has been their style with the previous releases, the form is demonstrated numerous times in front and rear views as well as at various speeds. There is also a long section in which the whole form is taught with instruction and corrections.>  A large section of the DVD is devoted to the applications of the moves. The history of Wudang sword is also covered on the DVD. An excellent section on sword drills is taught as well.>>  The sword drills could be considered the foundation of the sword form. Too many DVDs show the form, but not the drills that make up the foundation of the training so necessary to becoming skilled with the sword.>>  Over the years I have learned and taught the Chen and Yang style long forms of Taijiquan, Qin Na, Yang Sword and The Tung Family fast set of Taijiquan. I usually am not interested in learning new forms, but prefer to spend my time on enhancing, correcting and perfecting the forms I already know. However, this DVD was so inspiring, I now hope to learn this form. It is truly a magnificent sword set performed by a martial artist who shows tremendous potential at such a young age. Kudos to Zhou, Xuan-Yun and his collaborator David Silver.>>

reviewText: It is beautiful because of the quality of the demonstrations and instructions and also beautiful because the demonstrations are performed in exquisite environments: mountains in the background, forests, monasteries. It is a pleasure to watch this DVD and it is also very instructive.The DVD opens with a series of demonstrations of the form at various speeds with an excellent background narrative that explains the Daoist and taiji principles behind the martial art. The narrative include the "3 harmonies" and the balance of Yin and Yang. Qi and the sword. Harmony of sord and spirit. It continues with information about sword selection and care plus sword etiquette and the principles of Wudang sword.Next is a series of very clear sword training drills. This includes stance training drills. Horse stance, bow stance, fu stance, side stance and empty stance. Then comes footwork drills and sword handling drills.Then he goes through the Wudang Sword form step by step. Curiously the names of some parts of the form are the same as the names I learned for the Yang Taiji sword form even though the actual segments are different in the 2 forms. Part the Wild Horse's Mane, Cleaver Cat Catches the Mouse, Big Dipper points the Way, Push the Boat Down the Stream, etc.The last segment of the DVD covers Wudang Martial Applications.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This Wudaong sword DVD follows two previous DVD's by YMAA and Xuan-Yun Zhou,Wudang Kung Fu Fundamental Training, Basic Sequence, and ApplicationsandWudang Taijiquan (Tai Chi Chuan) 108 Form, which showcased the art of Wudang as well as helping to introduce new students to this wonderful Chinese martial art.As in the two previously mentioned DVD's, the instructor goes over each technique in minute detail to ensure that the student is as well versed as possible through watching this video. Throughout the video he discusses some of the subtle differences in each technique with the help of two assistants. I have always found this to be very helpful in showing some of the more common mistakes in order to then demonstrate proper technique and ways to avoid or at least fix the mistakes if they are made. Various camera angles during the execution of the form is also very helpful in giving the viewer a 360 degree view.The instructor also demonstrates the various applications for each technique in the form, and how it should be applied against another sword and also against a wooden staff. Also included in this DVD is a brief discussion on history and theory along with the cultural background of the Wudang.I have no reservations at all in giving this DVD my highest recommendation for those individuals wishing to learn the art of the Wudang Sword.Shawn KovacichCreator of numerous books and DVD's.
summary: Another Stellar Addition to the YMAA Library

reviewText: Wudang Sword-Powerful PoetryMaster Zhou, Xuan-Yun a Daoist from Wudang Mountain is beautiful to watch. This DVD is worth the price just for the opening chapter filmed in what appears to be Wudang Mountain.This Tai Yi Daoist Form is a series of sword work which includes incredibly fast strikes, swift turns and footwork, very low lunges, dragon turns, right and left and they are all performed with the outward appearance of an unworldly spirit. No fight in his face, only focused intention. Master Zhou is strong, balanced, light, swift and soft, all in the same breath. Poetry in motion.This DVD is rated at skill level one. That's a bit of a stretch if you have no experience at all with sword. If you know any sword forms and warm up or sparring drills, then level one it is.The instruction on the film is in English and Chinese, you can choose when you begin the play. No subtitles to distract. I find the narrators voice very easy to follow.He begins by giving a history of Sword play as weapon and a means to better health. There are some wonderful photos/paintings of the old masters. The shots of Master Zhou practicing in front of the temples in the mountains are stunning. Made me want to buy a ticket to China!There are short pieces about Sword etiquette, care of the sword and safety. A few warm up exercises are shown. I would have like to see more of them as well as warm up partner drills with the wooden practice swords. I think that would have been appropriate for a level one beginner disc.The Tai Yi Daoist Form is shown in slow motion and at real speed. Master Zhou also breaks down the movements, names them and uses them in application with a student.I do practice one short Yang style sword form that I learned about 10 years ago. My teacher at the time taught one move every two weeks, (four, one hour classes in each week). He would watch us do the move and then add the next one into the form. A slow way to learn, but very effective. Personally, I find it hard to stop the disc, practice a move, restart, again and again. I would like more repetition of the form, in sequence on a beginner dvd.Everyone learns at different rates. One thing for sure, the DVD gives a clear overview ofboth forms and applications. I especially like the list of movement names included in the packaging. I find it easier to remember forms if I know the name of the movement.This is a welcome addition to any Martial Arts library. Pure Power and Poetry.
